item.title: Sampling variance of Pearson r in a two-level design
item.description: Consider Pearsonâ€™s correlation coefficient, \(r\), calculated from two variables \(X\) and \(Y\) with population correlation \(\rho\). If one calculates \(r\) from a simple random sample of \(N\) observations, then its sampling variance will be approximately \[ \text{Var}(r) \approx \frac{1}{N}\left(1 - \rho^2\right)^2. \] But what if the observations are drawn from a multi-stage sample? If one uses the raw correlation between the observations (ignoring the multi-level structure), then the \(r\) will actually be a weighted average of within-cluster and between-cluster correlations (see Snijders & Bosker, 2012).
